ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how about the elements that create a piece of motion design and how to employ each technique. We were also exposed to a number of great designers and examples in the field. Given the time dedication needed to produce pieces of motion design, we also learned how to work incrementally, starting with a story board to a prototype to a finished product.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
One of the greatest strengths of the course was the workshops and time we spend critiquing each other's work. The weekly workshops leading up to the final critique for a project allowed me to refine my work and understand where I could improve. Furthermore, the final critiques were helpful in getting broad feedback from students. 

Additionally, I appreciated how much time we spent looking at professional and past student work. It served as an effective context for what was achievable. 

The only weakness I found was that the guest lectures often ran long. I felt like I learned more through the guest critiques than their presentations. 

One thing I would love is if we spent time learning about the techniques students used to create their videos. Since everyone enters the class with varying levels of expertise with After Effects, there were some people who employed much more advanced techniques than I did. I would have loved to learn how they accomplished the things they did.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Near the beginning of the semester, we concluded as a class that watching videos over screen share was not a good idea due to the buffer. As a result, Professor Pullman had us watch videos individually and discuss altogether. This was really helpful in keeping me engaged. 

Additionally, Professor Pullman gave us a lot of flexibility during workshops - we just had to arrive at our allotted time. This kept me from feeling Zoom fatigue, and I could be fully engaged when it was my turn to present.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, but only if you are willing to put in the work. This course is very rewarding if you are willing to make multiple drafts of the same project. You will get to see your idea transform in wonderful ways, but it does take a lot of time.
